worklogs.comment:
jgm-ktg commented on pull request #4372:  ARROW-5395: [C++] Utilize stream EOS in File format
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4372
 
 
   We currently do not write EOS at the end of a Message stream inside the File format.  As a result, the file cannot be parsed sequentially.  This change prepares for other implementations or future reference features that parse a File sequentially... i.e. without access to seek().

 ##########
 File path: docs/source/format/IPC.rst
 ##########
 @@ -104,7 +104,7 @@ Schematically we have: ::
 
     <magic number "ARROW1">
     <empty padding bytes [to 8 byte boundary]>
-    <STREAMING FORMAT>
+    <STREAMING FORMAT with EOS>
 
 Review comment:
   Someone should check if Java and JavaScript write the EOS

wesm commented on pull request #4372:  ARROW-5395: [C++] Utilize stream EOS in File format
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4372#discussion_r286624274
 
 

 ##########
 File path: cpp/src/arrow/ipc/writer.cc
 ##########
 @@ -1076,6 +1076,11 @@ class PayloadFileWriter : public internal::IpcPayloadWriter, protected StreamBoo
   }
 
   Status Close() override {
+    // Close stream for compatibility with sequential readers
+    RETURN_NOT_OK(UpdatePosition());
+    int32_t end_of_stream_marker = 0;
+    RETURN_NOT_OK(Write(&end_of_stream_marker, sizeof(int32_t)));
 
 Review comment:
   Can you move the `kEos` constexpr out of the `PayloadStreamWriter` to global scope and use that here? Then you don't need `end_of_stream_marker`
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

jgm-ktg commented on pull request #4372:  ARROW-5395: [C++] Utilize stream EOS in File format
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4372#discussion_r286658650
 
 

 ##########
 File path: docs/source/format/IPC.rst
 ##########
 @@ -104,7 +104,7 @@ Schematically we have: ::
 
     <magic number "ARROW1">
     <empty padding bytes [to 8 byte boundary]>
-    <STREAMING FORMAT>
+    <STREAMING FORMAT with EOS>
 
 Review comment:
   ```         return this
   +            ._writePadding(4); // eos bytes
                ._write(buffer) // Write the flatbuffer
                ._write(Int32Array.of(buffer.byteLength)) // then the footer size suffix
                ._writeMagic(); // then the magic suffix
   ```
   and
   ```   protected void endInternal(WriteChannel out) throws IOException {
   +    out.writeIntLittleEndian(0); // Write an EOS identifier for sequential readers
        long footerStart = out.getCurrentPosition();
   ```
   ? ...but I haven't figured out the testing yet

jgm-ktg commented on issue #4372:  ARROW-5395: [C++] Utilize stream EOS in File format
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4372#issuecomment-494988102
 
 
   > It occurs to me that we should probably add unit tests that the files can be iterated with a stream reader so this feature is not broken in the future
   
   ```import pyarrow as pa
   batch=pa.RecordBatch.from_arrays([ pa.array([1,None],type=pa.int32()) ], [ 'field1' ])
   
   with open('/tmp/test.batch','wb') as sink:
       writer=pa.RecordBatchFileWriter(sink, batch.schema)
       writer.write_batch(batch)
       writer.close()
   
   with open('/tmp/test.batch','rb') as source:
       reader=pa.ipc.open_stream(source.read()[8:])
       print(reader.read_pandas())
   ```
   
   This appears to be a good test case?  If agreed I will try to add it to the Python testing, which will catch any C++ problem as well.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

fields.description: We currently do not write EOS at the end of a Message stream inside the File format.  As a result, the file cannot be parsed sequentially.  This change prepares for other implementations or future reference features that parse a File sequentially... i.e. without access to seek().
